document.title:
C k
spaces and spaces of test functions

para.p:
Let
N
denote the set of nonnegative integers. For
∈ α
N n
, we write

Math.text: absolute-value@(alpha) = alpha _ 1 + cdots + alpha _ n

para.p: and

Math.text: partial-differential ^ alpha = ((partial-differential _ 1) ^ (alpha _ 1))@(cdots) * (partial-differential _ n) ^ (alpha _ n)

para.p:
We denote by
⁢
B r
( x )
the open ball with center
x
and radius
r
.

Let
Ω
be an open subset of
R n
and let
k
be either a nonnegative integer or
∞

⁢

( Ω )
to be the set of those functions
: f
→ Ω C
such that for each
∈ α
N n
with
≤
| α |
k

∂ α
f
exists and is continuous. We write
=
⁢ C
( Ω )
⁢
C 0
( Ω )
.

One proves that there is a sequence of compact sets
K j
such that each
K j
is contained in the interior of
K
+ j 1
and
= Ω
⋃
= j 1
∞
K j
; we call this an exhaustion of
Ω
by compact sets. For
∈ f
⁢
C k
( Ω )

Math.text: p _ (list@(k, N)) * f = (supremum _ (absolute-value@(alpha) less= minimum@(k, N)))@((supremum _ (x element-of K _ N))@(absolute-value@((partial-differential ^ alpha)@(f) * x)))

para.p:
this definition makes sense for
= k ∞
. If
f
is a nonzero element of
⁢

( Ω )

∈ x Ω
for which
≠

( x )
0
and then there is some
N

K N

⁢
p
k , N
( f )
≥
sup

K N
|
⁢ f
( y )
|
≥
|
⁢ f
( x )
|
> 0
. Thus,
p
k , N
is a separating family of seminorms on
⁢
C k
( Ω )
. Those sets of the form

Math.text: V _ (list@(k, N)) = conditional-set@(f element-of C ^ k * Omega, p _ (list@(k, N)) * f less 1 / N)

para.p:
form a local basis at
0
for a topology on
⁢
C k
( Ω )
, and because
p
k , N
is a separating family of seminorms, with this topology
⁢
C k
( Ω )
is a locally convex space. 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1 Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 27, Theorem 1.37. Because
p
k , N
is a countable separating family of seminorms, this topology is metrizable. We prove in the following theorem that
⁢ C
( Ω )
is a Fréchet space. 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 33, Example 1.44.

If

We have proved in Theorem that
=

( Ω )

( Ω )

If
Ω
is a bounded open subset of
R n

Math.text: C ^ infinity * overline@(Omega) = ((intersection _ (k = 0)) ^ infinity)@(C ^ k * overline@(Omega))

para.p:
It can be proved that
⁢
C ∞
(
¯ Ω
)
is the projective limit of the Banach spaces
⁢
C k
(
¯ Ω
)
,
= k
0 , 1 , …
. 3 footnote 3 3 footnote 3 See Paul Garrett, Banach and Fréchet spaces of functions, http://www.math.umn.edu/~garrett/m/fun/notes_2012-13/02_spaces_fcns.pdf A projective limit of a countable projective system of Banach spaces is a Fréchet space, and thus
⁢
C ∞
(
¯ Ω
)
is a Fréchet space.

Let
Ω
be an open subset of
R n
. If
: f
→ Ω C
is a function, the support of
f
is the closure of the set
{
∈ x Ω
:
≠
⁢ f
( x )
0
}
. We denote the support of
f
by
⁢ supp f
. If
⁢ supp f
is a compact set, we say that
f
has compact support, and we denote by
⁢
C c
∞
( Ω )
the set of all elements of
⁢
C ∞
( Ω )
with compact support. We write
=
⁢ D
( Ω )
⁢
C c
∞
( Ω )
.

For
∈ f
⁢ D
( Ω )
, we define

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ N = (supremum _ (absolute-value@(alpha) less= N))@((supremum _ (x element-of Omega))@(absolute-value@((partial-differential ^ alpha)@(f) * x)))

para.p:
If
K
is a compact subset of
Ω
, we define

Math.text: D * K = conditional-set@(f element-of (C _ c) ^ infinity * Omega, supp * f subset-of-or-equals K)

para.p:
The restriction of these norms to
⁢ D
( K )
are norms, in particular seminorms. Hence, with the topology for which a local basis at
0
is the collection of sets of the form
{
∈ f
⁢ D
( K )
:
<
∥ f ∥
N
1 N
}
, we have that
⁢ D
( K )
is a locally convex space, and because there are countably many seminorms
∥ ⋅
∥ N
, the space is metrizable. One checks that the topology on
⁢ D
( K )
is equal to the subspace topology it inherits from
⁢
